author: xtqqczze
body:
Build was attempted using Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.5.4

```
Error	NU1105	Unable to find project information for 'X:\PowerShell\src\Microsoft.Management.UI.Internal\Microsoft.PowerShell.GraphicalHost.csproj'. If you are using Visual Studio, this may be because the project is unloaded or not part of the current solution so run a restore from the command-line. Otherwise, the project file may be invalid or missing targets required for restore.	powershell-win-core	X:\PowerShell\src\powershell-win-core\powershell-win-core.csproj	1	
```

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body:
```
Error	NU1201	Project Microsoft.PowerShell.GraphicalHost is not compatible with netcoreapp5.0 (.NETCoreApp,Version=v5.0). Project Microsoft.PowerShell.GraphicalHost supports: net50 (.NETFramework,Version=v5.0)	powershell-win-core	X;\PowerShell\src\powershell-win-core\powershell-win-core.csproj	1	
```

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body:
The following commands ran once via the developer PowerShell allow me to build the solution in Visual Studio.
```
msbuild -t:restore; Import-Module ./build.psm1; Start-PSBuild
```

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: Honestly, we need a maintainer of the solution.  I don't use the solution because it's only problematic for me.  cc @daxian-dbw

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Usually VS public update is needed to work stable with latest .Net preview.

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body: @iSazonov Build was attempted using Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.5.4

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @xtqqczze We moved to TFM "net5.0" today. You could try with latest master.

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body:
Using 7c1cc868b, the solution fails to build from a clean workspace using "Build Solution" from within Visual Studio. It would therefore appear the move to `net5.0` does not affect this issue.

Additionally invoking `Start-PSBuild` fails too unless a manual [NuGet package restore](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-restore#restore-using-msbuild) is performed first with `msbuild -t:restore`.

As I indicated earlier, building from within Visual Studio suceeds as long as a command line build with `msbuild -t:restore; Import-Module ./build.psm1; Start-PSBuild` has suceeded previously.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
@xtqqczze `Import-Module ./build.psm1; Start-PSBuild` I always do this before trying to build with the solution.  I think this is expected.

Is the msbuild restore step really needed, because Start-PSBuild does that again if it's not already done.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: I've often found that in a clean workspace or after some commits have been pulled in I'll need to `Start-PSBuild -Clean` which prompts it to take a couple extra steps that seem to be required in certain cases.

comments.author: TravisEz13
xtqqczze
comments.body:
@vexx32 I have now found that if `Start-PSBuild -Clean` is used as you suggested than `msbuild -t:restore` is unnecessary.

@TravisEz13 It seems that if Visual Studio is opened before running `Start-PSBuild` then the environment becomes polluted somehow (likely from an automatic restore). I'm closing this issue but will open a new one concerning the build documentation as it is badly outdated.

comments.author: xtqqczze
comments.body: To resolve this issue `Import-Module ./build.psm1; Start-PSBuild -Clean` should be ran with Visual Studio closed. After building from the command line once, then "Build Solution" from within Visual Studio seems to work.

comments.author: iSazonov
TravisEz13
comments.body: I don't want to move it but it would be required for msbuild or visual studio to work perfectly

title: Failure to build when using Visual Studio 2019 without manual NuGet package restore
